title: 109_hr4066
content: The "Evacuees Tax Relief Act of 2005" allows for a credit for evacuation expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Evacuees Tax Relief Act of 2005" allows individuals to claim a tax credit for qualified evacuation expenses up to $5,000 per year. Qualified expenses include travel and other costs incurred during a qualified evacuation. The "Evacuees Tax Relief Act of 2005" allows individuals to claim a tax credit for qualified evacuation expenses such as travel, lodging, lost wages, and property damage not covered by insurance. Qualified evacuation refers to a voluntary or mandatory evacuation due to a qualified disaster. The credit allowance period includes the year of evacuation and the following three years. The tax credit is refundable up to $5,000 per year. The tax credit allowed under the "Evacuees Tax Relief Act of 2005" can be increased by the individual's social security taxes for the taxable year. This credit does not count towards the overall credit limit and reduces the amount of credit otherwise allowable. The term "social security taxes" is defined for this purpose. The term 'social security taxes' includes taxes imposed on amounts received by the taxpayer during the taxable year, self-employment income taxes, and taxes on amounts received during the calendar year. The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for special refunds under section 6413(c) and includes payments under agreements related to foreign affiliates. No double benefit is allowed for expenses eligible for deduction or credit elsewhere in the tax code. Individuals can choose not to apply this section. An individual may choose not to apply this section to qualified evacuation expenses for a taxable year. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a deduction for evacuation expenses. "SEC. 224. DEDUCTION FOR EVACUATION EXPENSES." The deduction for evacuation expenses allows individuals to deduct qualified evacuation expenses paid or incurred during the taxable year. The total deduction amount is limited to $5,000 for all taxable years. Qualified evacuation expenses include travel, lodging expenses up to $1,000, lost wages, and other related costs. The deduction for evacuation expenses allows individuals to deduct qualified evacuation expenses such as travel, lodging expenses up to $1,000, lost wages, and property damage not covered by insurance. Qualified evacuation is defined as a voluntary or mandatory evacuation due to a qualified disaster. No double benefits are allowed, and individuals can elect not to apply this section. The deduction for evacuation expenses can be elected not to apply by individuals. Amendments allow for the deduction regardless of itemizing other deductions. Clerical amendments are also made to the tax code. Amendments to the tax code include a new deduction for evacuation expenses, effective for taxable years ending after August 27, 2005.
